ai.summary: The Mary Towneley Loop is a demanding 195.4 km circular hike in the UK, intended for experienced walkers. It combines long days, sustained elevation, and varied upland landscapes that reward careful planning and solid navigation.
ai.terrain_summary: Predominantly upland moorland and valley trails with long ascents and descents, rocky and uneven paths, boggy sections, and exposed ridges. Terrain alternates between grassy moorland, rocky footing, and gravel tracks; navigation can be challenging in poor visibility.
ai.safety_notes: This is a long, hard multi-day trek with remote sections. Plan for either booked accommodation or camping. Check weather forecasts and daylight hours; wear sturdy footwear with good grip; bring map and compass (or a GPS) and know how to navigate. Tell someone your itinerary and daily targets; carry a means of communication and an emergency whistle. Bring sufficient food and water, plus a method to purify water. Be prepared for fatigue, slips on wet ground, and sudden weather changes; turn back if conditions deteriorate.
recommended_gear: Layered clothing (base layer, mid-layer fleece, outer shell)
Rucksack in the 20–40 L range with rain cover
Water bottle or hydration system + water purification method
ai.best_seasons: Late spring to early autumn (roughly May–September) is typically best in the UK, though weather can be unpredictable and upland conditions may be severe year-round.
